WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name Miss J.H. Conlin
Address 33 1/2 - 13 Ave., Regina
Birthplace Hollywood, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1904
Where did you set up housekeeping? 12 1/2 Ave., North of Regina
Where had you been living before that? Collingwood, Ont.
For how many people did you prepare meals? From 8 to 20
How far was it to your nearest store? 10 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? once or twice a week
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
mostly canned tomatoes - corn syrup - dried prunes & apples - flour, sugar, cereal, yeast

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs. packs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
How much did you use graham flour? about 20 lbs. per year
Whole wheat flour? very little
Was flour milled locally? No, far away? What year?
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
What other grain products did you use? Rolled Oats
Cornmeal? 4/10 Whole wheat? Farina? 4/10
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?
Conlin, Mrs. J.H., Regina.

Gormley? Yes

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Mostly cured.

Pork, wild game, venison, rabbit.

How did you get fresh meat? In winter, we butchered a beef.

How often did you get fresh meat? In summer, once a week.

How did you preserve meat? Curing, smoking.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so, what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Duck, Rabbit, Pheasant, Partridge, Pheasant, Chicken.

For how long? When meat was needed.

What part did fish play in the family diet? We could buy fresh fish, but not in winter.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Cured, canned, salmon.

Kinds? Salmon, catfish, pickerel.

(Handwritten note: Fresh fish in winter; canned fish in spring.)

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Mostly made own own

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Hard
Where did you get your fuel? From cliffs
Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.
Coal was used more extensively from around 1920
Electricity was being installed in country around 1946, north of Regina.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

**Breakfast**
- Rolled Oat porridge - fried potatoes - eggs
- Bread, butter - jam or syrup - coffee/tea
- Milk & cream

**Dinner**
- Soup, meat - Potatoes - pickles - Bread, butter
- Toffee - Pie - syrup or prunes - tea

**Supper**
- Pancakes - eggs - syrup - tea

20. Would you agree to be paid for your work?
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

We were more or less content, with meat, potatoes, canned tomatoes, pickles, hot brown rolls. Bread homemade, pan cake, and corn syrup was used very little for dessert. Then we were wanting a little extra. We served it with cream poured over it.

Before apples were on the market in Regina, we had apples shipped from Ont. in barrels. So had pies & sauce.

We grew the common variety of vegetables in gardens for ourselves use mostly - tomatoes or cucumbers.

Until about 1946 we grew no apple tomatoes - great green ones.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

By 1912 we could buy sweet vegetables in cans also some fruit - jams & pickles. Probably by 1915 we could buy pineapples.
